data.title: Pacers' Malcolm Brogdon wins J. Walter Kennedy Citizenship Award
authors: J. Michael and Michael McCleary, The Indianapolis Star
data.meta_description: In his first season in Indiana, Malcolm Brogdon is recognized for his outstanding service and dedication to the community.
data.text:
After his first season with the Indiana Pacers, Malcolm Brogdon has been voted the 2019-20 J. Walter Kennedy Citizenship Award winner, given by the Professional Basketball Writers Association, on Thursday.

The annual honor, named after the NBA’s second commissioner, is presented to a player, coach or athletic trainer who shows outstanding service and dedication to the community.

"I'm extremely honored to receive this award," Brogdon said. "It comes as a surprise, for sure."

Brogdon was selected from finalists that included Jrue Holiday (Pelicans), Kevin Love (Cavs), Josh Okogie (Timberwolves) and coach Lloyd Pierce (Hawks). Damian Lillard (Blazers) won the 2018-19 award.

"I was just looking at this list (of finalists). It had Kevin Love, LeBron (James), Damian Lillard," Brogdon said. "I mean, it had some high-profile names. And not just on the court, guys who are doing tremendous things to give others great opportunities.

"I think (James and other NBA players' efforts off the court) opens the door, it breaks the glass ceiling for players to know that, look, I have this money. Keeping it and spending it isn't the only way I can use it," he continued. "I can use it for good. I can use it to help other people transform other people's lives. So I think it's becoming more of the norm for guys."

The Brogdon Family Foundation was launched in July as the push for social justice reform heated up nationally after the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Brogdon was at the forefront, leading marches in his hometown of Atlanta and spearheading the Pacers' own efforts.

Brogdon worked with the team to increase voting access and partner with city and state leaders for criminal justice reform. He also is engaged with the JHA Education Project for literacy and mentoring and does Tuesday Talks with Malcolm for at-risk Black children in Indianapolis.

There's also his well-known Hoops2O and Hoops4Humanity partnership with the Chris Long Foundation that delivers clean water to east Africa by building water wells. In less than 2 years, he has helped raise almost $700,000 with other NBA and WNBA players.

"I'd like to just continue to expand it," Brogdon said. "There are hundreds of millions of people who don't have access to clean water across the globe."

The winner was determined by a vote of the entire PBWA, which is composed of more than 200 writers and editors who cover the NBA regularly for newspapers, magazines and online news outlets.

“The depth and breadth of Malcolm Brogdon’s commitment to making a positive difference is inspiring,” said PBWA President Josh Robbins of The Athletic. “Members of the Professional Basketball Writers Association salute him and commend his fellow finalists and nominees for their exemplary work.”

Reggie Miller is the only other player to honored as a Pacer, winning the award for the 2003-04 season. New Castle's Kent Benson won it in 1981-82.

Follow Pacers insider J.Michael on Twitter @ThisIsJMichael

Previous J. Walter Kennedy Citizenship Award winners

2018-19: Damian Lillard, Portland Trail Blazers

2017-18: J.J. Barea, Dallas Mavericks

2016-17: LeBron James, Cleveland Cavaliers

2015-16: Wayne Ellington, Brooklyn Nets

2014-15: Joakim Noah, Chicago Bulls

2013-14: Luol Deng, Cleveland Cavaliers

2012-13: Kenneth Faried, Denver Nuggets

2011-12: Pau Gasol, Los Angeles Lakers

2010-11: Ron Artest, Los Angeles Lakers

2009-10: Samuel Dalembert, Philadelphia 76ers

2008-09: Dikembe Mutombo, Houston Rockets

2007-08: Chauncey Billups, Detroit Pistons

2006-07: Steve Nash, Phoenix Suns

2005-06: Kevin Garnett, Minnesota Timberwolves

2004-05: Eric Snow, Cleveland Cavaliers

2003-04: Reggie Miller, Indiana Pacers

2002-03: David Robinson, San Antonio Spurs

2001-02: Alonzo Mourning, Miami Heat

2000-01: Dikembe Mutombo, Philadelphia 76ers

1999-00: Vlade Divac, Sacramento Kings

1998-99: Brian Grant, Portland Trail Blazers

1997-98: Steve Smith, Atlanta Hawks

1996-97: P.J. Brown, Miami Heat

1995-96: Chris Dudley, Portland Trail Blazers

1994-95: Joe O’Toole, Atlanta Hawks

1993-94: Joe Dumars, Detroit Pistons

1992-93: Terry Porter, Portland Trail Blazers

1991-92: Magic Johnson, Los Angeles Lakers

1990-91: Kevin Johnson, Phoenix Suns

1989-90: Doc Rivers, Atlanta Hawks

1988-89: Thurl Bailey, Utah Jazz

1987-88: Alex English, Denver Nuggets

1986-87: Isiah Thomas, Detroit Pistons

1985-86: Rory Sparrow/Michael Cooper, New York Knicks/Los Angeles Lakers

1984-85: Dan Issel, Denver Nuggets

1983-84: Frank Layden, Utah Jazz

1982-83: Julius Erving, Philadelphia 76ers

1981-82: Kent Benson, Detroit Pistons

1980-81: Mike Glenn, New York Knicks

1979-80: Austin Carr, Cleveland Cavaliers

1978-79: Calvin Murphy, Houston Rockets

1977-78: Bob Lanier, Detroit Pistons

1976-77: Dave Bing, Washington Bullets

1975-76: Slick Watts, Seattle SuperSonics

1974-75: Wes Unseld, Washington Bullets
